data.title: CSS Grid Bug coloring
Listing snippet prefixes and descriptions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:06:21.685Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0

---

I'd like a way to list all the snippets that are available for the current file. I have to either look up snippet definition files on github or use [_Trigger Suggest_](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/javascript#_snippets) and skim through the prefixes with other auto-complete entries mixed in.

This is particularly necessary for non-intuitive snippet prefixes added by extensions; the `Contributions` page does not include snippets.

data.title: No Format Document option in command pallette
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:16:18.034Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
csharp|ms-|1.12.0
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0
plsql-language|xyz|1.0.4



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Fresh install of v 1.15. I tried the following on a .cs file before and after installing csharp extension.
2. Command Pallete does not show "Format Document". Pressing Alt+Shift+F doesn't do anything. Pressing Ctrl+k, Ctrl+f says  "The key combination (Ctrl+k, Ctrl+f) is not a command.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: emmet.preferences support
data.body:
According to the blog [post](https://code.visualstudio.com/blogs/2017/08/07/emmet-2.0) about Emmet 2, the `emmet.preferences` was deprecated. 
Is there any other way to set preferences for Emmet? Some os those preferences are essential for me (and some other devs, i think).

data.title: PowerShell formatting and indent bug when using the backtick character
JSX syntax highlighting breaks when using default values for destructred parameter
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:06:21.685Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- sort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0 project-manager|ale|0.19.0 path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2 vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11 RelativePath|jak|1.0.0 cpptools|ms-|0.12.2 final-newline|sam|0.3.2 highlight-matching-tag|vin|0.4.4 (2 theme extensions excluded) --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a new file and set the language mode to "JavaScript React" 2. Add the following code: ``` const button = ({ className }) => (
Click me!
); ``` 3. Add a default value for `className` in the destructured object parameter: ``` const button = ({ className = 'button' }) => (
Click me!
); ``` 4. After this change, observe that JSX syntax highlighting is broken. ![jsx-syntax-broken](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7561061/29282042-51328700-80ef-11e7-9714-0e04b056fe49.gif) Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Version 1.16 "Release Notes" has bad GitHub query
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (b73b7df1290d0fe66ca8b8060743711a327af622, 2017-08-14T05:16:07.578Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install new Insiders build.
2. Look at "Release Notes: 1.16.0-insider".
3. Click "Closed bugs" or "Closed feature requests".

Expected: GitHub is launched with results.
Actual: GitHub is launched with "No results matched your search." because the milestone query isn't in quotes. Repros in Chrome and Edge.

data.title: Make snippet highlights themeable
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15
- OS Version: win7x64

Can someone tell, what setting is responsible for highlighting the "next label" in the "snippet mode"?

Cause, for example, I have this snippet "setAttribute(\"${1:attr}\", \"${2:value}\");$0"
but if you will look at the screenshot, I think you won't say that there is any highlighting on **"value"**, it's extra faded.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29277572-b63dd94e-811a-11e7-91e0-7ba737125203.png)

data.title: Emmet doesn't expand my abbreviation
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15 x64
- OS Version: Win 10 Pro x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I use "div.column.is-2[data-num=$]*6>div.circled>img+(.circled>p{ })" and then try to expand it with edit menu's option "Emmet: expand..."
2. I get an error "Running the contributed command:'emmet.expandAbbreviation' failed." or I get only a single "p" tag expanded.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No
Yes

data.title: Replicate Atom's add new project capability
data.body:
Say I want to split screen to compare my code to code written in a directory not available in the current **explorer pane**  I don't think you can do this currently in VS Code.

If I have `~/Documents/code` open in the **explorer pane** and now I want to also have `~/Stuff/Code` open at the same time in the **explorer pane**. The way VS Code is currently configured, a new folder will open in a new window. I would like the have the new folder available in the same **explorer pane**.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15
- OS Version: win7x64

Suggestions in settings - pretty nice idea. BUT. There will be no suggestions after you will remove 1 or more letters after typing something.

For example, I type "snipp", then remove one letter to "snip", and that's it! VS Code will not show you any suggestions after this. Until you will remove everything including quote marks. That's annoying, guys!

![settings - suggestions](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29276499-7a363444-8117-11e7-95f8-0d87c60bec56.gif)

data.title: Debugging: preLaunchTask window behavior not user-friendly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (b73b7df1290d0fe66ca8b8060743711a327af622, 2017-08-14T05:16:07.578Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
vscode-babel-coloring|dza|0.0.4
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
cpptools|ms-|0.12.2
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.7
vetur|oct|0.9.3
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0
rust|rus|0.2.1
debug|web|0.21.2

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

I wanted to start the pretty neat debugging functionality for my Rust code. I'm using the Native Debug extension to debug my executable, but need to run my `build` task before to ensure that I always have the most recent version of my code built. This ends up in a kind of unfriendly behavior for me because the window always switches to "Terminal" when running the build task but does not switch back to "Debug Console" afterwards. I think it makes a lot of sense to either switch to the Debug Console if I was on there before when the `preLaunchTask` finished with exit status 0 or do not switch to the Terminal at all.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Configure a Build Task
2. Configure a Debug Task with `preLaunchTask` set to the Build Task
3. Switch to the "Debug Console"
4. Start Debugging (F5)
5. notice how the window goes to "Terminal" but does not switch back to Debug Console.

*Demonstration*: [Screen Recording (1.06MB)](https://in.fkn.space/i/2017-08-14_16-03-36-9a7ac213.mp4)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No (no debugger available for me)
